body.p: Let’s check out the skeletal system in action in the following case study.

One afternoon, 74 year old, Anne Teak was walking down the steps in her home to answer the front door. With a sharp cry of pain, her hip gave way and Anne fell down the steps. Luckily, her granddaughter, Sarah, was at the door, heard the noise and ran into the house. She saw Anne lying at the bottom of the steps, crying in pain.
“What happened, grandma?” Sarah worriedly asked, as she quickly dialed 911 for an ambulance.
“I don’t know,” Anne cried. “I was walking down the steps when I felt a sharp pain in my hip, my leg gave out underneath me and I fell down the steps.”

The ambulance quickly arrived and took Anne and Sarah to the local emergency room. There, an x-ray confirmed a fractured femur. The ER doctor, Dr. Brown, spoke to Anne, Sarah, and Sarah's mother, Susan. The doctor explained that Anne’s bones were very weak and that she has a disease known as osteoporosis.

“The bone cells that make bone are not working as fast as the cells that break bone down and Anne’s bones are becoming weaker.” Dr. Brown told them. “In fact, Anne’s femur broke because it was too weak to support her weight and that is why she fell, she didn’t break her femur from the fall.”
“What can be done to help my mother’s bones become stronger?” Susan asked.

Dr. Brown replied, “Bones are living tissues that respond to stress. Exercising and eating a diet high in calcium can help bone tissue become stronger. Your mother will need a cast to protect the healing bone and then she will start physical therapy so we can strengthen the bones and the muscles.”

As you know, homeostasis is the ability of an organism to regulate its internal environment so that normal functioning continues. In fact, disease often occurs when the body loses control over homeostasis. Some diseases, such as Anne’s osteoporosis, occur when the bone mineralization decreases to the point where the bones become weaker (less able to withstand forces on them). This leads to increased risk of fractures, sometimes even with normal functioning. In this example, Anne was just walking down the stairs when her femur broke.

Bones are not the dried out structures you often see in lab. They are crucial contributors homeostasis. As mentioned in the homeostasis unit, the skeletal system contributes to the maintenance of blood calcium levels. Blood calcium is necessary for cardiac, and smooth muscle contraction, as well as for determining how easy it is to stimulate all forms of muscle cells to contract. Calcium is also important for blood clotting, neuron and hormone function. The bones are a storage site of calcium. If blood calcium levels decrease, such as not getting enough in one’s diet, calcium is taken from the bones and put into the blood. This makes bones weaker. When blood calcium levels increase, extra calcium is deposited into bones for storage. This makes bones stronger. If Anne follows Dr. Brown’s recommendation she will make sure she eats plenty of calcium to ensure she has enough intake to maintain blood calcium levels, as well as enough extra that can be deposited into her bones.

Bones also protect organs. Think about how easy trauma could damage your brain, spinal cord, heart, and lungs if they were not protected by bone. Bone is very strong yet typically has some flexibility, which makes it the perfect tissue for this function.

One other important role of bones is in hemopoiesis (hematopoeisis). Bone tissue contains red bone marrow which contains the stem cells for the formation of all blood cells. The stem cell is known as the hemocytoblast and ultimately forms all red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets. Red blood cells are critical for transporting oxygen and carbon dioxide in the blood. White blood cells are the main cellular component of our immune response, and platelets are necessary for hemostasis (blood clotting).
